node.title: Discontinuous boundary conditions
node.bodyText:
I'm solving a system of coupled equations (heat + diffusion) for a system of concentric rings. There is a gap between the rings, which I would rather not model, that leads to a difference in temperature between the inner-right and outer-left boundaries of the rings. I can specify these as a Dirichlet boundary condition (time-dependent function). I also have a relationship that defines the concentration at either side of the interface as a function of the temperature.
Do I need to use XFEM to model something like this?  If so, how would I specify a function-based Dirichlet boundary condition, and how would I specify an equilibrium relationship across the boundary?
This sounds like something that our Constraints System might handle. I have not used it, perhaps @lindsayad or @bwspenc could verify that I am understanding correctly.
That looks right. I'll update if/when I get it working.
I think you're looking for GapHeatTransfer: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/GapHeatTransfer.html

That might be a good starting point. Still new here so my terminology might be off, but I would almost describe temperature as an auxiliary variable. I still need to calculate the temperature profile, but I have time-dependent values of the temperature at each edge of each gap. I need to calculate the equilibrium concentration across the gap, assuming fast gas-phase transport. I do have an equation for that. Would you recommend me starting with GapHeatTransfer and extending it?

node.title: Error running Peacock
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm pretty new to Moose and Linux in general, I think I have everything set up correctly but I'm still getting errors when trying to run a simulation through peacock. This is the error:
moose) [aliyay@aliya-hpspectrex360convertible15ch0xx peacock]$ ./peacock
No executable found for method type(s): opt, dbg, oprof, devel
QXcbConnection: XCB error: 3 (BadWindow), sequence: 2300, resource id: 10515013, major code: 40 (TranslateCoords), minor code: 0
QXcbConnection: XCB error: 3 (BadWindow), sequence: 2904, resource id: 10517754, major code: 40 (TranslateCoords), minor code: 0
QXcbConnection: XCB error: 3 (BadWindow), sequence: 3590, resource id: 10519280, major code: 40 (TranslateCoords), minor code: 0
QXcbConnection: XCB error: 3 (BadWindow), sequence: 3953, resource id: 10526005, major code: 40 (TranslateCoords), minor code: 0
WARNING
Problem running '/home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined/practice/workshop2/model_A_equilibrium.i -options_left 0 --json'
WARNING
Failed to load json from '/home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined/practice/workshop2/model_A_equilibrium.i': Problem running '/home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined/practice/workshop2/model_A_equilibrium.i -options_left 0 --json'
Error: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined/practice/workshop2/model_A_equilibrium.i'
This says the issue is the permissions but when I check them, it says I should be able to execute these files.
(moose) [aliyay@aliya-hpspectrex360convertible15ch0xx workshop2]$ ls -la
total 124
drwxr-xr-x 3 aliyay aliyay  4096 Mar 17 11:43 .
drwxr-xr-x 4 aliyay aliyay  4096 Mar 17 11:26 ..
drwx------ 2 aliyay aliyay  4096 Mar 17 11:42 .jitcache
-rw-r--r-- 1 aliyay aliyay    74 Mar 17 11:43 model_A_eq_1D.csv
-rw-r--r-- 1 aliyay aliyay 85384 Mar 17 11:43 model_A_eq_1D.e
-rw-r--r-- 1 aliyay aliyay    13 Mar 17 11:42 model_A_eq_1D_x_direction_0000.csv
-rw-r--r-- 1 aliyay aliyay  2494 Mar 17 11:43 model_A_eq_1D_x_direction_0001.csv
-rwxrwxrwx 1 aliyay aliyay  2704 Mar 17 11:23 model_A_equilibrium.i
-rwxrwxrwx 1 aliyay aliyay  2620 Mar 17 11:23 model_A_growth.i
-rwxrwxrwx 1 aliyay aliyay  2577 Mar 17 11:23 model_A_shrinkage.i
-rwxrwxrwx 1 aliyay aliyay  2658 Mar 17 11:23 model_A_shrinkage_n_growth.i
I'm not sure what the issue is. Any help is appreciated.

You have not compiled your code:  "No executable found for method type(s): opt, dbg, oprof, devel". If you are new I suggest working through out tutorial. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial01_app_development/index.html

The error lies in line right after you executed peacock:
No executable found for method type(s): opt, dbg, oprof, devel
While you may have built modules, or the the combined module in particular, Peackock does not know how to search that direction. Peacock will search for binaries at your current working directory, and work 'backwards' (parent directory):
/home/aliyay/projects/moose/python/peacock
  nope. Go up one directory.
/home/aliyay/projects/moose/python
  nope. Go up one directory.
/home/aliyay/projects/moose
  nope. Go up one directory. Woops. We hit the root directory, tell the user:
`No executable found for method type(s): opt, dbg, oprof, devel`
What you need to do, is build the combined module, and then run peacock from either that location, or from the location of your chosen input file (because combined-opt will exist in a parent directory from that location):
cd /home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined
make     # if you haven't done so already
cd /home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined/practice/workshop2
/home/aliyay/projects/moose/python/peacock/pecock -i model_A_equilibrium.i
That's a lot of paths... Which is why we suggest created a PATH to Peacock so that you can just execute peacock no matter where you are along the file system:
export PATH=/home/aliyay/projects/moose/python/peaock:$PATH
cd /home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined/practice/workshop2
peacock
(of course, the same applies: you must have a binary built somewhere in your parent directories).
I would also suggest throwing that export PATH=/home/aliyay/projects/moose/python/peaock:$PATH in your bash profile, so it is always set.

node.title: Water97FluidProperties Problems
node.bodyText:
Hi All,
I want to use drho_dT in the rho_from_p_T() function in ADMaterial, but when I was typing:
_"Real rho, drho_dp, drho_dT;
_fp.rho_from_p_T(_press[_qp],_temperature[qp],rho,drho_dp,drho_dT)"
the errors occurred:
"no matching function for call to 'SinglePhaseFluidProperties::rho_from_p_T.'"
and"candidate expects 2 arguments, 5 provided."
How can I use drho_dT?
Thanks,
Yuhang

Hello
Since you are using an ADMaterial you may want to leverage AD to compute the derivatives.
@lee7632 has a recent fix for these properties and should be able to help
Guillaume
Yes. I use the fluid property of drho/dT in ADkernel, thus I need to build it in ADMaterial. I don't know how to use the drho_dT in Water97FluidProperties?

Are _press and _temperature AD variables? If so, that won't work, you would need _press[qp].value() or similar.
But if they are AD, then why not use DualReal rho = rho_from_p_T(_press, _temperature) and then rho has the derivative you want?

Thank you for your replies.
The _press and _temprature are AD variables, and _press[qp].value() still doesn't work.
If I use DualReal rho = rho_from_p_T(_press, _temperature), the rho can be obtained, but I want to get drho/dT rather than rho.

Thank you for your patience!
For the first way:
The errors in Terminal are as shown:
_Creating Unity /home/1/projects/zebra/build/unity_src/material_Unity.C
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/1/projects/zebra/build/unity_src/material_Unity.C...
In file included from /home/1/projects/zebra/build/unity_src/material_Unity.C:5:0:
/home/1/projects/zebra/src/material/TwophaseADMaterial.C: In instantiation of ‘void TwophaseADMaterial< >::computeQpProperties() [with ComputeStage compute_stage = (ComputeStage)0u]’:
/home/1/projects/zebra/src/material/TwophaseADMaterial.C:663:1:   required from here
/home/1/projects/zebra/src/material/TwophaseADMaterial.C:255:3: error: request for member ‘value’ in ‘(&((TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>)this)->TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>::_press)->MooseArray::operator[](((TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>)this)->TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>::.ADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>::.Material::_qp)’, which is of non-class type ‘const double’
_fp.rho_from_p_T(_press[_qp].value(),_temp_liq[_qp].value(),rho,drho_dp,drho_dT);
^
/home/1/projects/zebra/src/material/TwophaseADMaterial.C:255:3: error: request for member ‘value’ in ‘(&((TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>)this)->TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>::_temp_liq)->MooseArray::operator[](((TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>)this)->TwophaseADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>::.ADMaterial<(ComputeStage)0u>::.Material::qp)’, which is of non-class type ‘const double’
make: *** [/home/1/projects/zebra/build/unity_src/material_Unity.x86_64-pc-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1
For the second way:
How can I get the index of the temperature variable on the current point(_qp)?
What should I do?
Best wishes!
I just checked the first way you tried and it definitely works (it's actually how the AD function is implemented). You must have a typo, or the variables aren't AD, or an old moose version, etc.
Can you make your code available so we can take a look? It might make this easier.

Thank you for your reply,
I have solved this problem. Maybe the reason is that I have an old moose version.
When I used MetaPhysicL::raw_value(_press[_qp]) instead of _press[_qp].value(), it worked!
Thank you again for your patience！
Best wishes!

node.title: Initializing Solution in Newton Iterations
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am solving a transient problem. I would like to know whether it is possible to initialize the solution before the Netwon iterations for each timestep begin?
Best,
Nikhil
You can look into the Predictor system. We have objects in that system that extrapolate past solutions to obtain a better guess. However you'll be dealing with raw DOF value access.

node.title: Add output data after the simulation is over
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
Recently, I recently completed a simulation and output the strain (the three strain components in 2D), but now I want to output the stress component again. Now, could I get the stress data on the basis of previous simulations without recalculating?
This is the moose example I used，poly_grain_growth_2D_eldrforce.i.
Any suggestions or recommendations to fix these problems would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you
Wei Peng

Give this a try:
[Outputs]
  [out]
    type = Exodus
    additional_execute_on = FINAL
  []
[]

Thank you very much. @aeslaughter
According to your suggestion, I modified the Outputs module and added sub-blocks that require output stress in AuxKernel, Input file is as follows
poly_grain_growth_2D_eldrforce_0.i 
and then executed the code,
mpirun -np 10 ~/projects/monkey/monkey-opt -i poly_grain_growth_2D_eldrforce_0.i > poly_grain_growth_2D_eldrforce_0.log 
But this method shows that it is recalculated.
Could you talk more about it?
Can you give me more information, I don't understand "But this method shows that it is recalculated." What method shows what is recalculated?

@aeslaughter I think he means, he wants to use stress calculated from his first simulation directly on his second simulation without re-calculating it.

Now, could I get the stress data on the basis of previous simulations without recalculating?

Yes, what I want to do is to directly obtain the stress component data on the basis of my first simulation, instead of recalculating the model after modifying the input file.
In detail, the exodus file now contains strain components (three in two dimensions) and the Euler angle of each grain. Knowing the elastic stiffness tensor, how to pass Hooke's law
to get the stress component?

Hi, for uploading the data from .e file, you might want to have a look at 'initial conditions + restart'
`use_for_exodus_restart = true

`initial_from_file_var`

but for the 2nd part of your q, I'm not sure either, I'm also very new to MOOSE.
Is it possible to calculate material property before running the FEM simulation? It might got something to do with AuxKernals
Could someone help with this? thank you :)

Wei, you should use solution aux https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/SolutionAux.html and solution user object https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobject/SolutionUserObject.html to read in your previous results.
In your Problem block, set solve = false, i.e.
[Problem]
  solve = false
[]

to skip the solve.
Keep everything else the same, and just add a stress calculator.

This should work, but only disable the solve if the calculations being done in the second input file are not solving a PDE. Sorry I did understand your initial condition and lead you down the wrong path.

Thank you very much for your enthusiastic help.
I am not very familiar with some functions of moose, so I solved this problem with paraview. Given the strain component, Euler angle, and elastic modulus without rotation, use the generalized Hooke's law to solve. Of course, if you has a more detailed plan based on moose, and I am happy to try it.

node.title: Activate AMR only after criterion?
node.bodyText:
Is it easy to set in the input file to activate AMR only after percent change in energy, F, is below a certain value? Say: if dF/dt = 1e-3 start to aggressively coarsen?
I also seem to have problems getting the simulation to immediately refine down to max_h_level and stay that way. Say for example I use:
initial_steps = 5
but I want ALL elements (and not just markers/indicators) to be refined down to this until dF/dt = 1e-3 when the markers/indicators kick in. Then it should coarsen the domains (image attached).
Things are looking peachy here in ferroelectrics land (big thanks to @SudiptaBiswas for helping us get the "thin film" boundary conditions working).
cheers
John

Hi John
I dont think AMR can be turned on/off using the Control system.
However you could use an AuxVariable to control the refinement criteria, and those could be set using a criterion like the one you mentioned.
Guillaume

It should be possible to create a control that does, but it might be just as easy to create a custom Marker object that can check the criteria. It could use or not-use the results from another marker.

I am still thinking about this.

We have an order parameter that is a vector whose components start near zero and small. And randomly oriented so they possible have large gradients. We ideally want to refine down (so value threshold could work initially) but we don't want to refine too far at the early stages.

But later in the simulation the value of some of the components are much larger but some could be small still!

At this point we want to have maximum refinement near the phase field interface but maximum coarsening far away. It's pretty tricky. I will try to post a small example...

Get Outlook for Android<https://aka.ms/AAb9ysg>
…
________________________________
From: Andrew E Slaughter ***@***.***>
Sent: Wednesday, March 17, 2021 9:36:39 PM
To: idaholab/moose ***@***.***>
Cc: Mangeri, John ***@***.***>; Author ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [idaholab/moose] Activate AMR only after criterion? (#17125)


*Message sent from a system outside of UConn.*


It should be possible to create a control that does, but it might be just as easy to create a custom Marker object that can check the criteria. It could use or not-use the results from another marker.

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fidaholab%2Fmoose%2Fdiscussions%2F17125%23discussioncomment-495616&data=04%7C01%7Cjohn.mangeri%40uconn.edu%7C23ce1c5ae7f044fb4df408d8e9845e82%7C17f1a87e2a254eaab9df9d439034b080%7C0%7C0%7C637516102021675356%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=L9gmf2fWjqJH%2F9Bzc9%2FboPqQoZXoguOMETY6Ds0hRzo%3D&reserved=0>, or unsubscribe<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fnotifications%2Funsubscribe-auth%2FABZ65FBW3OMIMVLDU3KTR6DTEEHFPANCNFSM4YFGGA4Q&data=04%7C01%7Cjohn.mangeri%40uconn.edu%7C23ce1c5ae7f044fb4df408d8e9845e82%7C17f1a87e2a254eaab9df9d439034b080%7C0%7C0%7C637516102021675356%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=37%2FgRgtqeh5wEER9ejWdkaPInKGcGIABDiU2m425OJ0%3D&reserved=0>.
Sounds like a case for a custom marker. I made one a long while ago to track a phase-field interface but account for the direction of travel and marked more in the direction of travel.

This makes sense. As our domains (in the above image) merely coarsen until we kill the simulation. This is what I aim to tackle with the AMR.
In the above picture, the domain walls (interface between "phases") lie at inclined planes. An example, being [110] and all symmetry equivalent directions.
It would be nice to not have to assume this direction of the propagating wall for the Marker/Indicator since different materials have symmetry specific wall angles with respect to a global axis and these can change drastically with temperature.

node.title: Calculation of elastic modulus gives Euler angle
node.bodyText:
Hi all，
I use Euler angles to rotate the elastic stiffness matrix. I only give the first Euler angle 45° and the other two to 0°. Then according to C_ijkl = R_im*R_jn*R_ko*R_lp*C_mnop, the specific calculation is as follows, But the C1111 calculated manually is different from the C1111 calculated by the program running.

The manually calculated c1111 is 1.1729e5, and the moose calculated c1111 is 1.7245e5.

What is the problem with me?
The following is the process of my calculation and the input file used.


  [./elasticity_euler] type = ComputeElasticityTensor block = 0 base_name = 'euler' fill_method = symmetric9 C_ijkl = '1.27e5 0.708e5 0.708e5 1.27e5 0.708e5 1.27e5 0.7355e5 0.7355e5 0.7355e5' euler_angle_1 = 45.  # same as above but opposite direction because _transpose_ gets built from these angles euler_angle_2 = 0. euler_angle_3 = 0. [../]
rotation_matrix_1_rotation.i
Thank you and best regards, Wei
Did you try rotating by -45 degrees? According to the documentation, the Euler angles are used to calculate the transpose of the rotation matrix due to the Bunge convention.
Also I think that with 4 indices (ijkl) that can either be 1 or 2, you should have at least 8 terms in your summation.

Thank you very much for your guidance. @jessecarterMOOSE
I already know where my problem is and have overlooked some items. The following is my revised process, I hope other people will not make the same mistake as me.

node.title: Solving steady-state problem using explicit solver?
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
Is there a way to solve a steady-state problem using explicit method?
I know MOOSE is optimised with implicit, but my problem is kinda large (couple million elements) and require to run many steady-state simulations (with a minor change in material property at each run), so my supervisor suggests me to work with explicit solver instead.
Ive attached a simplify version the input file (tensor mech with implicit) here.
implicit_to_explicit.zip
Thank you guys.
Kind regards,
Traiwit

I'm not sure that your question makes sense, @Traiwit .   "Implicit" and "explicit" usually refer to the timestepping method, but if you're doing steadystate only then there is no time.  To put it differently - to achieve steadystate, you'd have to time-step to infinity, which would take an explicit solver an infinite amount of time.

Thank you for your answer Andy, I just realised that I didn't think of the fundamental of FEM.
I'm now kinda dig myself into a hole with this mining simulation i'm trying to build.
I might work on quasi-static instead (you suggested a while ago), where after the elastic steady-state is reached > change the marterial property of 1 block > run steady-state simulation again > repeat.
I'm not sure if MOOSE can do that, I know it's quite simple with for-loop. This might worth posting in a new discussion.

If you do that, you probably want to run it in a single simulation.  Make the model transient but have no time-derivative (velocity, acceleration, etc) Kernels.  Then each timestep will be solving the steady-state problem, ie, you'll be doing a quasi-static simulation.  The "time" in these simulations isn't a real time, but is simply to help you divide up the mining excavations into stages.  Eg, set dt=1, and in the first timestep you mine stage 1, in the next timestep you mine stage 2, etc.  So the notion of "time" essentially allows you to do your "for loop" idea.
An associated advantage is that you can, if you wish, shove in some time-derivative kernels, and solve the dynamic problem (you'll probably need damping), which can help with convergence when you've got complicated plasticity, and you can use an explicit method if you like.

Hi Andy, thank you for your reply.
Do you have (or can think of) any example for this quasi-static simulation? I tried to make the input file transient, but the error said 'i'm the a wrong state' for some reason, maybe because I do not have 'time' term anywhere in the input file.
again, thank you!

@WilkAndy I read your coal-mining example, I see your problem works well with quasi-static as you set the ecavation as a function of time and location
[./excav_sideways]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 'end_t ymin ymax  minval maxval slope'
    vals = '17.0   0    1000.0 1E-9 1 60'
    # excavation face at ymin+(ymax-ymin)*min(t/end_t,1)
    # slope is the distance over which the modulus reduces from maxval to minval
    value = 'if(y<ymin+(ymax-ymin)*min(t/end_t,1),minval,if(y<ymin+(ymax-ymin)*min(t/end_t,1)+slope,minval+(maxval-minval)*(y-(ymin+(ymax-ymin)*min(t/end_t,1)))/slope,maxval))'
  [../]

However, is it possible to do quasi-static with mining-step plan associate with block ID for example
t = 1 // excavate block 1 2
t = 2 // excavate block 3 4 5
t = 3 // excavate block 6 7 and backfill block 2
etc ...
with my very little knowledge of MOOSE, i doubt MOOSE can do what i mentioned above in a single input file.
I could do that by running each steady-state simulation using the solution from previous step.
what do you think?
Best regards,
Traiwit

Yes, this is quite easy.   Just define an appropriate ParsedFunction .  It'll look horrible, eg
value = 'if(t<=1, if(y<2000, 1, 0), if(t <=2 , if(y<5000 & y >= 2000, 1, 0)))'

Hi Andy, very interesting that MOOSE can do that, and I agree it will be very messy if the excavation blocks are 3D in the middle of the geometry. I will give it a go and get back to you.
I just hope that it can be done via blockID instead of defining the dimensions
for example: at t=1 E of block1 = 0 & E for all the other blocks remain the same as the previous step
Kind regards,
Trai

That will be no problem, since you can define your ElasticityTensor block-by-block and deactivate it using it's own elasticity_tensor_prefactor.   Real mining probably happens more like a MovingPlanarFront which allows you to specify a start position, an end position, a mining velocity, and an active_length (which could be your void, for instance).

Hi @WilkAndy thank you again for your suggestion, I will give it a go and probs get back to you in the afternoon.
Kind regards,
Traiwit

@WilkAndy it works, but if my input has like 400+ blocks i might need a script to write an input file.
Now, I fill need to work with backfilling and then I can move on to plasticity.
again, thank you very much for your support!
Below is the example case, 0 = geology block, 1 2 3 = excavating blocks

[Functions]
[./E_excav1]
  type = ParsedFunction
  value = 'if(t>=1,10e-4,1)'
[../]
[./E_excav2]
  type = ParsedFunction
  value = 'if(t>=2,10e-4,1)'
[../]
[./E_excav3]
  type = ParsedFunction
  value = 'if(t>=3,10e-4,1)'
[../]

[./density_excav1]
  type = ParsedFunction
  value = 'if(t>=1,1.225,2700)' # air density or rock density
[../]
[./density_excav2]
  type = ParsedFunction
  value = 'if(t>=2,1.225,2700)' # air density or rock density
[../]
[./density_excav3]
  type = ParsedFunction
  value = 'if(t>=3,1.225,2700)' # air density or rock density
[../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]

[./elasticity_tensor_0_unmined]
  type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
  block = '0'
  youngs_modulus = 20e9
  poissons_ratio = 0.25
[../]
[./elasticity_tensor_1]
  type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
  block = '1'
  youngs_modulus = 20e9
  poissons_ratio = 0.25
  elasticity_tensor_prefactor = E_excav1
[../]
[./elasticity_tensor_2]
  type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
  block = '2'
  youngs_modulus = 20e9
  poissons_ratio = 0.25
  elasticity_tensor_prefactor = E_excav2
[../]
[./elasticity_tensor_3]
  type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
  block = '3'
  youngs_modulus = 20e9
  poissons_ratio = 0.25
  elasticity_tensor_prefactor = E_excav3
[../]

[./density_0_unmined]
  type = GenericConstantMaterial
  block = '0'
  prop_names = density
  prop_values = 2700
[../]
[./density_1]
  type = GenericFunctionMaterial
  block = '1'
  prop_names = density
  prop_values = density_excav1
[../]
[./density_2]
  type = GenericFunctionMaterial
  block = '2'
  prop_names = density
  prop_values = density_excav2
[../]
[./density_3]
  type = GenericFunctionMaterial
  block = '3'
  prop_names = density
  prop_values = density_excav3
[../]
[]

node.title: error installing libmesh on a HPC cluster (petsc-3.14.2)
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
We are having some problematic times trying to upgrade our moose/libmesh installation on our internal cluster - while installing libmesh. Attached the config.log file.
Note: for the first time, I did not install manually petsc (3.14.2), but used the script from the framework. Had problems with the direct solver strumpack (deactivated), but I do not think it matters.
Before re-installing manually everything, I was wondering if anyone could see what I am missing.
Thank in advance for any help,
mauro

config.log

Dear all,
I am re-opening this post, since I cannot find a solution to the problem above.
I should add that I am able to compile an older version of the framework (specific commit 54c00d0) against petsc version 3.12.5 (manually compiled). However I cannot upgrade to the newest version. I am installing petsc (3.14.2) relying on the procedure as per the website. I checked the installation and all worked fine., but while trying to build libmesh it always fails with the same error as I posted above (I can link again the log file in case).
It would be nice if anyone from the developer team and/or users group could help me sorting out this issue.
Thanks in advance for any help,
Mauro

Attached the whole build.log (>4 MB) file for libmesh in case it could be of any help (the config.log is as for the one above and it looks OK to me at least)
build.log

Hi Mauro
Is this fixed? I ll tag people who may be able to help if not

Thanks for your reply @GiudGiud.
The problem still persists, though I did not (re)try to compile. This said, I would much appreciate any guidance in this respect.
Looking forward to feedback.
Mauro
I saw this 28 days ago, and I still don't have an idea... @roystgnr or @lindsayad ?
@fdkong was working on push_parallel_vectors lately he might have an idea too
It could be an "old" compiler. Could you should the result of "mpicxx -show"?
We should definitely still be supporting 7.2; if not then that's something that we should fix or workaround on our part.  But it couldn't hurt to try a newer compiler to confirm or rule that out.

Oh, wait!  Just looked at your build.log.  We've seen this once before - the trouble is likely that we've started requesting more recent C++ standards support by default, but some older compilers accept the flags to support newer standards, pass our configure-time tests with those flags on, but then fail to actually compile our code.
Try forcing an older standard by configuring libMesh with --cxx-std=2011 and see if that works any better.
We really need @jwpeterson to work his m4 C++ standard testing magic

The trouble here is that I'm not even sure how we'd write a test for this problem.  It's not a missing feature that we're running into; it'seems to be a compiler bug that gets triggered by a very complex piece of code.  It'd be a ton of work to boil it down into a test small enough for an autoconf macro that still triggers the same problem.
I'd say we should just downgrade the level of C++ we ask for, since we don't need C++17 yet, but I've been hoping we could actually upgrade to need (and thus to be able to internally use) C++17 later this year, now that even the conservative RHEL distributions default to gcc 8.  But if people are still using gcc 7.2 and if it's responsible for this build failure then perhaps I'm being too optimistic?  gcc 7 is supposed to have full C++17 support too, in theory, but in practice here we are.

@roystgnr and all other: Thanks! I really had some terrible time trying to figure out what I was doing wrong ...
I will set up myself to it tomorrow (CET) and will report asap.

After upgrading to gcc 9.2 libmesh install without any problem. @roystgnr: your guess was right. Though I thought I did try to force the 11 standards before, but surely I did mix things up. Thanks for the support.

node.title: Using AD with constitutive models
node.bodyText:
Hi:
I would like to place a set of constitutive models into a file so that they can be called by multiple ADMaterial objects.  Is it possible to propagate AD info back from these functions to the ADMaterial?  If so, what should they inherit from?  Can they just be utility functions?
For example, an ADMaterial calls a function "getHTC(Re, Pr)" where it is declared:
ADReal getHTC(ADReal Re, ADReal Pr);
Would something like that work?  Is there a good example to follow?
Thanks,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
This would work, the derivative information stored in the Reynolds and Prandtl number will be propagated in the function (provided ADReals are used inside too) to the output.
There are good examples in pronghorn. For example in materials/PebbleBedKappaSolid.C
For the inheritance question, I think maybe the thing to do is to have all these utility functions be member functions of a class, and have the ADMaterial you are creating inherit from that class. Pronhorn does that for all the closures that are similar and sharing utility functions.
Just separate utility functions can also work.
Best,
Guillaume

Thanks Guillaume.
I thought that might be the case but some text in the AD documentation confused me.  Namely:
"Leveraging the automatic differentiation capabilities in MOOSE is as simple as inheriting from our AD base classes, e.g., ADKernel, ADIntegratedBC....".
As there isn't an ADUserObject base class, I wasn't sure if AD would work with methods that inherit from UO's.
Thanks,
Joe
